Nearly 1,300 New York Times Employees Are Protesting Return-to-Office Policies by Staying Home@Observer9/12/2022

Editorial and tech workers are refusing to go into the office as part of a union action in protest of the newspaper’s return-to-office policy and lack of progress in negotiating a contract.

				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Nearly 1,300 New York Times Employees Are Protesting Return-to-Office Policies by Staying Home</h1>
					<h2 class="dek">Editorial and tech workers are refusing to go into the office as part of a union action in protest of the newspaper's return-to-office policy and lack of progress in negotiating a contract.</h2>

		<p>Nearly 1,300 <a href="https://observer.com/company/new-york-times/" title="New York Times" class="company-link">New York Times</a> employees signed a pledge to work remotely this week, rather than return to the office as expected, the union representing employees of the newspaper <a target="_blank" target="_blank" rel="noopener" href="https://twitter.com/NYTimesGuild/status/1569314118888312832?s=20&t=JgvpP9_BSm7YtX9g_96Qag" data-lasso-id="1831419">announced</a>. Employees with the New York Times Guild, which represents reporters and editors, are joined by members of the union representing Times tech workers. Union members with Wirecutter, the newspaper’s paid product recommendation service, signed the pledge in solidarity. Though Times union workers are part of separate units, they’re all represented by the News Guild of New York.</p>

<p>In a statement shared <a target="_blank" target="_blank" rel="noopener" href="https://twitter.com/NYTimesGuild/status/1569314124739256320?s=20&t=8AGGebusXygrpksW4BB7BQ" data-lasso-id="1831420">on Twitter</a>, the New York Times Guild said the company’s “expected return” policy it not based on any bargained agreement. “Any RTO policy, as a matter of workplace health and safety, should be a part of our negotiated contracts, alongside provisions for fair wages, equitable treatment for members & more,” the union said.</p><div data-ad="1" class="ad-wrapper ad-top-margin ad-has-disclaimer ad-incontent ad-mobile htlad-observer_article_instream_mobile_1" id="observer_article_instream_mobile_1"></div><div class="ad-wrapper ad-top-margin ad-desktop ad-has-disclaimer ad-incontent htlad-observer_article_instream_dsk_1" id="observer_article_instream_dsk_1"></div>
<p>The New York Times <a target="_blank" target="_blank" rel="noopener" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/05/22/business/hybrid-work-office.html" data-lasso-id="1831421">previously said</a> it wanted employees back in its headquarters by June 6, but put a pause on these plans due to the city’s high Covid levels. The company <a target="_blank" target="_blank" rel="noopener" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/08/28/business/the-offices-last-stand.html" data-lasso-id="1831422">recently set</a> “fresh guidelines” for bringing workers back into its New York City headquarters in September, according to workplace reporter Emma Goldberg. While the Times is rewarding returning employees with branded lunch boxes, the union said instead it wants a “respect and a fair contract, without delay.”</p>
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-width="550" data-dnt="true">
<p lang="en" dir="ltr">The <a target="_blank" target="_blank" rel="noopener" href="https://twitter.com/nytimes?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">@nytimes</a> is giving employees branded lunch boxes this week as a return-to-office perk. We want respect and a fair contract instead — so I’m working from home this week along with 1,300 of my <a target="_blank" target="_blank" rel="noopener" href="https://twitter.com/NYTimesGuild?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">@NYTimesGuild</a> and <a target="_blank" target="_blank" rel="noopener" href="https://twitter.com/NYTGuildTech?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">@NYTGuildTech</a> colleagues, with support from <a target="_blank" target="_blank" rel="noopener" href="https://twitter.com/wirecutterunion?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">@wirecutterunion</a>.</p>
<p>— Emma Goldberg (@emmabgo) <a target="_blank" target="_blank" rel="noopener" href="https://twitter.com/emmabgo/status/1569324684184899586?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">September 12, 2022</a></p></blockquote>
<p><script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script></p><div data-ad="1" class="ad-wrapper ad-top-margin ad-has-disclaimer ad-incontent ad-mobile htlad-observer_article_instream_mobile_2" id="observer_article_instream_mobile_2"></div><div class="ad-wrapper ad-top-margin ad-desktop ad-has-disclaimer ad-incontent htlad-observer_article_instream_dsk_2" id="observer_article_instream_dsk_2"></div>
<p>New York Times Guild members are currently negotiating with management <a target="_blank" target="_blank" rel="noopener" href="https://nypost.com/2022/08/02/new-york-times-employees-very-angry-over-stalled-pay-discussions/" data-lasso-id="1831423">for a new contract</a>; the previous one expired more than a year ago.</p>
</p>

readabilityObject.title: Nearly 1,300 New York Times Employees Are Protesting Return-to-Office Policies by Staying Home
readabilityObject.content:
Nearly 1,300 New York Times employees signed a pledge to work remotely this week, rather than return to the office as expected, the union representing employees of the newspaper announced. Employees with the New York Times Guild, which represents reporters and editors, are joined by members of the union representing Times tech workers. Union members with Wirecutter, the newspaper’s paid product recommendation service, signed the pledge in solidarity. Though Times union workers are part of separate units, they’re all represented by the News Guild of New York.

In a statement shared on Twitter, the New York Times Guild said the company’s “expected return” policy it not based on any bargained agreement. “Any RTO policy, as a matter of workplace health and safety, should be a part of our negotiated contracts, alongside provisions for fair wages, equitable treatment for members & more,” the union said.

The New York Times previously said it wanted employees back in its headquarters by June 6, but put a pause on these plans due to the city’s high Covid levels. The company recently set “fresh guidelines” for bringing workers back into its New York City headquarters in September, according to workplace reporter Emma Goldberg. While the Times is rewarding returning employees with branded lunch boxes, the union said instead it wants a “respect and a fair contract, without delay.”

The @nytimes is giving employees branded lunch boxes this week as a return-to-office perk. We want respect and a fair contract instead — so I’m working from home this week along with 1,300 of my @NYTimesGuild and @NYTGuildTech colleagues, with support from @wirecutterunion.

— Emma Goldberg (@emmabgo) September 12, 2022

New York Times Guild members are currently negotiating with management for a new contract; the previous one expired more than a year ago.

  • SEE ALSO: Anatomy of a Slogan: Suggestions for the ‘Efficiency Department’
